Oh memory!  thou busy source of pain!</br>Thou actor of our miseries o'er again!</br>Thou harsh intruder!  whose tormenting pow'r,</br>Instilling thought embitters every hour;</br>Forego thy bitter unrelenting sway,</br>Nor doom to horrours every coming day.</br>Ah what avails imagination's powers</br>With fancied bliss to cheat the tardy hours,</br>Whose sweet delusions banish care away</br>And to the mind bestow perpetual day;</br>If the sad soul is wrapp'd in joyless gloom</br>And sighs and lingers for the welcome tomb.</br>The sun with boundless glory fills the skies</br>And myriads joys where fair Hindostan lies:</br>Yon silver orb with fainter beams invite</br>The pensive muse each phylosophick night,</br>Those heavenly spheres resplendent gild the pole</br>And tell what hand supports and rules the whole.</br>Springs verdant charms now deck the joyful land,</br>And bounteous nature spreads with lavish hand,</br>Whilst ev'ry grove with feather'd choirs resounds</br>And richest paintings fill the smiling grounds,</br>When Summer heats prevail, the clown oppress'd,</br>Hies to the shade and lays him down to rest;</br>Whilst the dark wood a sweet asylum shows</br>Where the rap't soul with inspiration glows:</br>And Autumn next displays her reapen'd plain</br>Crown'd with rich fruits and fill'd with golden grain.</br>All, all, in vain. — The universe bestows</br>No charms, no pleasures, to deceive his woes.</br>The woodland warbling jars his sated ear—</br>The country lies a desart — wild and drear—</br>He wisely shuns the silent solemn glade</br>For harsh reflection haunts the gloomy shade.</br>Autumnal riches no new bliss supply;</br>They nothing yield to please the mental eye,</br>See, icy Winter chearless reigns around</br>And cities throng'd with mirth and joy abound;</br>The bliss which from the social mixture flows,</br>No gaiety, no happiness bestows;</br>Forlorn, unhappy, wretched, does he feel;</br>And prove how hard the task an anguish'd mind to heal.</br>Say from what source, can memory impart,</br>One pleasing sense to sooth the murderer's heart?</br>When busy fancy brings the injur'd shade</br>To haunt his solitude, his peace invade?</br>The guilty wretch, who waded to the throne</br>Thro' kindred blood, from danger conscious grown,</br>Now by the trembling limb and bloodless cheek</br>Betrays his crimes; nor can a refuge seek</br>From bleeding forms, who bare the mangled breast,</br>And to his frighten'd vision stand confest—</br>Behold that wretched tyrant youth expire;—</br>His frame consumed by more than mortal fire;</br>Stung by remorse, not all the charms of art,</br>Could hush his cares, or ease his aching heart:</br>Each hour recalls, the bloody dreadful day,</br>When by his mandate thousands slaughter'd lay,</br>When in cold blood confounding youth and age</br>His wretched subjects felt his bigot rage.</br>O, friend to Virtue!  whose all powerful aid,</br>Sooner or later owns the heav'nly maid;</br>In terrours cloth'd, the villain's mind assail;</br>And with just vengeance tear aside the veil,</br>That from himself his hideous portrait hides</br>And for his crimes a lasting scourge provides.</br>See the proud monument and marble bust,</br>With useless pomp insult the humble dust;</br>Whilst gorgeous pageants more supremely show,</br>That all parade is mockery of woe;</br>Unheeded by the father, lover, friend,</br>Who o'er the grave in silent anguish bend—</br>Will no kind genius watch the fatal hour,</br>And blunt the invidious tyrant's baleful power?</br>Lull with a syren's spells the aching sense,</br>And to the mind lethargick aid dispense?</br>Ah no — for all is horrour and dismay;</br>While yet the husband hugs the breathless clay.</br>Ten thousand thousand sad illusions rise</br>To aid his anguish and increase his sighs—</br>Now is recall'd each hour, each happy day</br>That smooth'd life's passage of the dreary way;</br>Now do contrasted pleasures mock his woes,</br>And to impending grief, lost virtue's charms oppose.</br>When the loud gate's tempestuous force descends,</br>And sharpest light'ning heav'ns vast concave rends;</br>Whilst thro' the crackling rigging howls the storm,</br>And naught prevails but tumult and alarm;</br>Then to the youthful breast of him who roves,</br>Far from the mistress whom he fondly loves;</br>Malicious mem'ry proves her hated art</br>And emulates the vile tormentor's part,</br>O, cursed gold!  the source of various woe;</br>From whom our sorrows more than pleasures flow:</br>In search of thee, I brav'd the faithful seas,</br>To gain by added fortune future ease:</br>For visionary wealth I wildly roam,</br>And madly leave my plighted love and home;</br>Fool, not to know, that competence was bliss,</br>And certain happiness exchange for this!</br>Let me again behold my native shore,</br>And I will tempt th' uncertain waves no more.—</br>But most when madness rules th' unhappy hour</br>Must wretched man sustain thy keenest power;</br>All other sense of joys or sorrows gone,</br>And the whole soul absorb'd with one alone.</br>Hail!  thou great master of the magick pen</br>Whose piercing eyes beheld the hearts of men;</br>Hast thou not forc'd the sympathetick tear</br>With the keen horrours of thy frenzy'd Lear?</br>When to his comfort ev'ry door was clos'd,</br>And bare he stood to pelting storms expos'd;</br>The fretful elements contend in vain,</br>They hurt not him whose agonized brain</br>Dwells on a father's violated right,</br>And tells his sorrows in the ear of night,</br>While rain, and storm, and lightning, all conspire</br>To aid "th' unnat'ral hags" against their sire.</br>Remembrance, ever constant, points the pain,</br>Shews him his wrongs, and tells them o'er again;</br>For when in lonely hovel he descries,</br>In seeming madness where sad Edgar lies,</br>Poor wretch, says he, thy fate is hard indeed;</br>Naught but ingratitude has done this deed.</br>Where far remote some desart island lies,</br>Midway in seas, and curs'd by wintry skies,</br>Some shipwreck'd mariner perchance now strays</br>A hapless wand'rer, doom'd to pass his days</br>'Midst barren rocks, where hideous monsters roar,</br>And tempests rage forever round the shore;</br>From mankind banish'd he must ever weep,</br>And curse the fate which sav'd him from the deep;</br>Happy would sweet oblivion prove but kind,</br>And blot remembrance from his wretched mind:</br>Oft at the ling'ring close of cheerless day,</br>What time is seen afar Sol's parting ray</br>Gleam o'er the deep:  the scenes long past arise;</br>His throbbing bosom heaves with struggling sighs;</br>Sad, in despair, he views th' extended main,</br>And thinks on joys he ne'er must see again.</br>But oh, what bliss!  when on the farthest verge</br>Of distant horizon, the faithless surge</br>Wafts towards his ravish'd sight a distant sail;</br>Oh with what extacies he feels the gale</br>That onward brings the long, long wish'd for aid,</br>So long to his unceasing prayers delay'd.</br>Alas!  stern Fate relentless heeds no sigh;</br>For see, the unconscious vessel passes by</br>With rapid motion., leaves the aching sight,</br>And all is lost in one unbounded night.

Say, who to dulness' stupid sway consign'd,</br>All pleasing thoughts of happiness resign'd?</br>Reflecting, dwells on scenes enjoy'd before,</br>And not laments those scenes to come no more?</br>Thus the poor exile from his native home,</br>By ruthless force, abroad compell'd to roam;</br>Whether from Afric or from Callia driven,</br>Sees for his portion naught remain but heav'n:</br>In foreign countries doom'd to beg or toil,</br>With heart-corroding grief reflects the while</br>On his dear native land, and former ease,</br>And those lov'd scenes where all was wont to please:</br>Whilst this with unavailing grief complains,</br>Of ruin'd fortunes, and usurp'd domains.</br>For such, Compassion heaves the sorrowing sigh,</br>Whilst social tears suffuse soft Pity's eye.</br>But say, ye grasping avaricious fools,</br>In whom the love of money only rules;</br>Who with insatiate wants forever curs'd,</br>Behold the doom of prosp'rous fate revers'd;</br>Say, can you claim of sympathy the meed?</br>For your distress what pitying heart will bleed?</br>The proffer'd boon of competence was naught;</br>Unbounded wealth your greedy purpose sought,</br>Yet bless'd with all that mortals could implore,</br>Your narrow, sordid hearts still grasp'd at more;</br>Still for superfluous riches spent those hours,</br>Ordain'd to exercise far nobler powers—</br>Now doom'd in poverty your days to close,</br>And with departed joys contrast impending woes.</br>Thee!  sad Remembrance, we then fly in vain,</br>By thee reflection brings continuous pain,</br>Thy constant power the art of man defies,</br>Times past incessant to his thoughts arise:</br>Alas!  how few th' intrusive view can bear?</br>How oft excited, starts Contrition's tear?</br>Yet not alone art thou to self confin'd;</br>With other woes th' historian wrings the mind:</br>'Tis but to seek the thicket's inmost shade,</br>Possess'd of Clio's stores implore their aid;</br>Instant we pierce the distant maze of time,</br>And view the ills of ev'ry age and clime;</br>O then what gloomy objects rise to view!</br>In the long lapse of time, behold how few</br>The friends of virtue and of good appear,</br>With casual joy to check the constant tear.</br>Life's varied scenes delusive seem, and vain,</br>Producing naught but sorrow, grief, and pain;</br>And this sad truth forever wounds the mind,</br>That man's most deadly foe is human kind.</br>In vain the eager eye with ardour pores</br>On classick pages, and the time explores,</br>When Roman virtue and the patriot's pride</br>To gods above, the human soul ally'd.</br>Ages of crime and wretchedness succeed,</br>The wicked triumph, and the virtuous bleed;</br>Whilst monster tyrants in succession show</br>The sad varieties of human woe;</br>And long old Rome is seen in sullied state,</br>Her freedom sacrificed to factious hate.—</br>Extend our views; regard the christian world;</br>The crescent, and the cross, behold unfurl'd;</br>The red-cross banner waves o'er Europe's land,</br>And christian rage and folly now command:</br>Still human blood in streams perpetual flow,</br>The baleful flames of persecution glow,</br>And Heav'n's meek child, Religion, sacred maid!</br>To desarts flies, and seeks Retirement's shade:</br>There with her God in peace secure remains,</br>Whilst all the world her sacred name profanes.</br>The tyrant's pretext, and the Impostor's aid;</br>See for destruction drawn the murd'rous blade.</br>In Gallia's land, on Belgium's hapless shore,</br>Holy fanaticks lavish human gore.</br>A bigot woman — Britain's lasting shame,</br>There, points the sword, or blows the cruel flame.</br>Now warriour monarchs peaceful realms invade,</br>To gain those laurels which may never fade;</br>The battle ended, and the millions slain,</br>Say, is the victor's brow entwin'd in vain?</br>Long shall they flourish? — Yes, the tyrant's name,</br>Th' indignant page will damn to lasting fame.—</br>The bloody thirst of gold contemn'd the waves,</br>And ravag'd shores the southern ocean laves;</br>The name of Cortez pains the sorrowing mind;</br>Pizarro's fame to ages goes consign'd.—</br>Hence, dismal visions!  leave my wearied soul—</br>O come, some pow'r, the baleful thoughts controul—</br>Leave me not wrapp'd in one eternal night,</br>But with enchantment charm my blunted sight—</br>It comes — it comes propitious to my view;</br>'Tis no deceit, great WASHINGTON, 'tis you!</br>O ever present to the wond'ring mind,</br>Be all thy virtues, all thy deeds confin'd:</br>So shall fair nature boast one brilliant light</br>To cheer in history's page the constant night.</br>
